papers.title: A Narrowband Technosignature Search Toward the Hycean Candidate K2-18b Using the VLA and MeerKAT
papers.abstract: K2-18b, a sub-Neptune exoplanet located in the habitable zone of its host star, has emerged as an important target for atmospheric characterization and assessments of potential habitability. Motivated by recent interpretations of JWST observations suggesting a hydrogen-rich atmosphere consistent with Hycean-world scenarios, we conducted a coordinated, multi-epoch search for narrowband radio technosignatures using the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array equipped with the COSMIC backend and the MeerKAT telescope with the BLUSE backend. Our observations span frequencies from 544MHz to 9.8GHz and include multiple epochs that cover at least one full orbital period of the planet. In this work, we outline, create, and apply a comprehensive post-processing framework that incorporates observatory-informed RFI masking, drift-rate filtering based on the expected dynamics of the K2-18 system, multibeam spatial discrimination, primary and secondary transit filtering (when applicable), and SNR-based excision of weak and strong spurious signals. Across all bands and epochs, no signals consistent with an astrophysical or artificial origin were identified at a limit of 10¬π¬≤ to 10¬π¬≥W. These non-detections allow us to place upper limits on the presence of persistent, isotropic narrowband transmitters within the K2-18 system, providing the first interferometric technosignature constraints for a Hycean-planet candidate. Our results demonstrate the efficacy of coordinated multiepoch interferometric searches and establish a methodological framework for future technosignature studies of nearby potentially habitable exoplanets.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Scientists have discovered thousands of planets orbiting other stars, but finding signs of life‚Äîor even intelligent life‚Äîremains one of astronomy's greatest challenges. K2-18b, a planet about twice Earth's size located 120 light-years away, has captured attention as a potentially habitable world with a hydrogen-rich atmosphere and possible water vapor. If advanced civilizations exist on such planets, they might be broadcasting radio signals into space, just as humans have been doing for over a century. This study represents humanity's first serious attempt to "listen" for artificial radio transmissions from this promising world, marking a new chapter in our search for cosmic neighbors.

**What They Did**

Researchers used two of the world's most powerful radio telescope arrays‚Äîthe Very Large Array in New Mexico and MeerKAT in South Africa‚Äîto scan K2-18b for artificial radio signals. Think of it like tuning across a cosmic radio dial, searching for narrow-frequency broadcasts that could only come from technology, not natural sources. They observed the planet system multiple times over several months, covering a complete orbit of K2-18b around its star. The team developed sophisticated computer programs to filter out Earth-based interference from cell towers, satellites, and other human technology, while specifically looking for signals that would move in sync with the planet's motion through space‚Äîa telltale sign of an extraterrestrial origin.

**Key Findings**

The search came up empty‚Äîno artificial signals were detected from K2-18b. However, this non-detection is scientifically valuable, allowing researchers to rule out the presence of powerful radio transmitters broadcasting at least 10 trillion watts of power (roughly equivalent to all of Earth's current electrical power generation). Any civilization using radio technology at this level or higher would have been spotted by the telescopes.

**Looking Forward**

While this study found no evidence of alien technology, it established a crucial methodology for future searches around other potentially habitable worlds. As more Earth-like planets are discovered and our radio telescopes become more sensitive, this systematic approach brings us closer to answering one of humanity's most profound questions: are we alone?

papers.title: Limits on the Post-eclipse Emission Spectrum of HD 80606 b From High-Resolution Spectroscop
papers.abstract: We present Keck/NIRSPEC K-band observations of HD 80606 b, one of the most eccentric known exoplanets. HD 80606 b was observed after secondary eclipse, close to periastron, when the planet passes within 0.03 AU of HD 80606 and the rapid heating of the atmosphere may lead to extreme chemical changes and a temporary thermal inversion. The rapid change in the planetary radial velocity near periastron is sufficient to enable high-resolution cross-correlation spectroscopy (HRCCS) analysis, which produces a tentative detection ( SNR 4) of HD 80606 b. Injection-recovery tests appear to reject strong thermal inversions near periastron, consistent with recent results from JWST. We also perform atmospheric retrievals with free parameters for the Pressure-Temperature (P-T) profile and with a profile matched to the JWST results, which suggest the presence of absorption features from CH‚ÇÑ and CO. While HD 80606 b is not definitively detected in these data, these results are consistent with JWST observations, which found the post-eclipse atmosphere of HD 80606 b shows weak absorption features from these species. Future observations with higher spectral resolution and/or wider wavelength coverage are needed for a confident atmospheric detection of HD 80606 b via high-resolution spectroscopy alone, but such observations are a challenge to schedule due to the 111-day orbital period.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine a planet so close to its star that its surface could melt lead, then so far away it becomes a frozen wasteland‚Äîall within the same year. HD 80606 b is one of the most extreme worlds we know, following a wildly stretched orbit that makes it a natural laboratory for understanding how planetary atmospheres respond to dramatic temperature swings. By studying this cosmic oddball, scientists can learn how weather and chemistry work on planets unlike anything in our solar system. This research helps us understand the incredible diversity of worlds beyond Earth and pushes the boundaries of our planet-hunting technology.

**What They Did**

The researchers used one of the world's most powerful telescopes‚Äîthe Keck Observatory in Hawaii‚Äîto analyze infrared light from HD 80606 b just after it passed behind its star (called a secondary eclipse). They focused on the moment when the planet was closest to its star, experiencing scorching temperatures that could fundamentally alter its atmosphere. Using a technique called high-resolution cross-correlation spectroscopy, they essentially created a chemical fingerprint of the planet's atmosphere by examining how different molecules absorb specific wavelengths of light. Think of it like using a prism to split sunlight into a rainbow, but looking for tiny dark lines that reveal what gases are present in the planet's air.

**Key Findings**

The team found tentative evidence of the planet's atmosphere, though the signal was relatively weak. Their analysis suggests the presence of methane and carbon monoxide in the planet's atmosphere, which aligns with recent observations from the James Webb Space Telescope. Importantly, they found no evidence of a "thermal inversion"‚Äîa phenomenon where upper atmospheric layers become hotter than lower ones, like Earth's ozone layer but more extreme. This finding contradicts some predictions about what should happen when this planet gets blasted by intense stellar radiation during its close approach.

**Looking Forward**

These results demonstrate both the potential and challenges of studying extreme exoplanets. While the findings align with cutting-edge space telescope observations, they highlight the need for even more sensitive instruments to definitively characterize such distant worlds. Future observations could reveal how planetary atmospheres evolve in real-time under extreme conditions, offering insights that could reshape our understanding of planetary science and guide the search for habitable worlds.

papers.title: Characterisation of starspot structure and differential rotation of Kepler-411
papers.abstract: Starspots and their movements on stellar surfaces enable investigating the mechanisms of stellar magnetic activity. Information on the spot distribution and differential rotation provide important constraints for the behaviour of stellar magnetic dynamos. We analyse the Kepler photometry of Kepler-411, a known exoplanet host, to determine the distribution and properties of star spots on the stellar surface with two independent and complementary methods: modelling the photometric effect of rotation of spots on the stellar surface and mapping of spots by transiting planets. By constructing a spot model accounting for geometry, differential rotation and spot evolution, we model the spots of the stellar surface giving rise to the observed brightness variations. We also search for evidence for occultations of starspots in high-cadence photometry. Our spot models reproduce the observed photometric variations well and we are able to obtain information on the distribution and movement of spots on the stellar surface. We do not obtain evidence for differential rotation -- the rotational profile is consistent with rigid-body rotation with a period of 10.52¬±0.34 days. We detect three occultations of spots by planet c. The positions of these spots coincide well with the positions of larger spot structures identified by our modelling of the rotational modulation of the light curve.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Just like our Sun has dark spots that move across its surface, other stars throughout the galaxy also have these mysterious features. Scientists are fascinated by starspots because they're like windows into a star's magnetic personality‚Äîrevealing how its magnetic field behaves and changes over time. When these spotted stars happen to host planets, researchers get a unique opportunity to study both the star and its planetary system together. Understanding how stars work is crucial because they power all life as we know it, and their behavior directly affects any planets orbiting around them, including whether those worlds could potentially support life.

**What They Did**

The research team studied a star called Kepler-411, which is known to have at least two planets orbiting around it. They used data from NASA's Kepler Space Telescope, which watched this star continuously for years, measuring tiny changes in its brightness. Think of it like having a super-sensitive light meter pointed at the star 24/7. The scientists used two clever detective methods: first, they tracked how the star's brightness flickered as dark spots rotated in and out of view, like watching shadows move across a spinning ball. Second, they looked for brief dimming events when the star's planets passed in front of spots during their regular orbits‚Äîessentially using the planets as scanning devices to map where spots were located on the star's surface.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that Kepler-411 rotates like a rigid spinning top, completing one full rotation every 10.52 days (compared to our Sun's 25-day rotation period). Surprisingly, they found no evidence that different parts of the star rotate at different speeds, which is common in stars like our Sun. They successfully caught three instances where one of the planets, called planet c, passed directly over starspots, causing tiny but measurable dips in brightness. These spot locations matched perfectly with their computer models, confirming their mapping technique works.

**Looking Forward**

This research demonstrates powerful new ways to study distant stars and their planets simultaneously. By understanding how starspots behave, scientists can better predict how stellar activity might affect planetary atmospheres and climates‚Äîcrucial information for assessing whether exoplanets could harbor life.

papers.title: The Y Dwarf Population with HST: unlocking the secrets of our coolest neighbours -- III. Near-Infrared Photometry
papers.abstract: Y dwarfs represent the coldest class of brown dwarfs, with effective temperatures below 500K, and provide unique analogues to cold giant exoplanets. We present a large compilation of uniform near-infrared photometry from the Hubble Space Telescope for 21 Y dwarfs across multiple WFC3/IR filters, including the F105W, F125W and F160W bands. We employed refined PSF-fitting and calibration procedures to reach photometric uncertainties at the 0.02-0.05 mag level for most targets. Combined with precise parallax measurements, our data reveal well-defined Y-dwarf sequences in near-infrared colour-magnitude diagrams, observed with a markedly improved tightness. Known photometric trends emerge with minimal scatter, including the continuous redward progression in F125W-F160W with decreasing temperature, and the blueward trend in F105W-F125W with possible hints of a reversal around 350K. Comparisons to the ATMO, Sonora Elf Owl, and Lacy & Burrows atmospheric models highlight systematic discrepancies, in particular F105W-F125W and F105W-F160W colours predicted to be too red. Low-metallicity grids provide the best fits to the global Y-dwarf population, although closer inspection across wavelengths shows that these preferences likely reflect compensating effects in missing or incomplete physics rather than true population-level abundances. While some atmospheric diversity is expected among Y dwarfs, their tight observational sequences and systematic offsets from model predictions reveal that key physical and chemical processes remain inadequately captured in current grids. Our results underscore the importance of high-precision, internally consistent datasets in robustly tracing the Y-dwarf cooling sequence and providing the empirical constraints needed to advance theoretical models at the lowest temperatures.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand distant worlds by studying the coldest, faintest objects in our cosmic neighborhood. Y dwarfs are "failed stars"‚Äîobjects too small to ignite nuclear fusion‚Äîwith surface temperatures cooler than your kitchen oven. These dim brown dwarfs are cosmic laboratories that help us understand giant planets orbiting other stars, since they share similar temperatures and atmospheric conditions. By studying these nearby examples in detail, astronomers can better interpret the faint signals we detect from actual exoplanets billions of miles away. It's like having a reference library of planetary atmospheres right in our galactic backyard.

**What They Did**

The research team used the Hubble Space Telescope to take extremely precise photographs of 21 Y dwarfs through different infrared filters‚Äîessentially cosmic color filters that reveal how bright these objects appear in specific wavelengths of light invisible to human eyes. Think of it like photographing the same object through red, green, and blue filters to understand its true colors. They developed sophisticated techniques to measure the brightness of these incredibly faint objects with remarkable precision, achieving accuracy levels comparable to distinguishing between a 100-watt and 102-watt lightbulb from across a football field. They also used precise distance measurements to create detailed charts showing how these objects' colors and brightness relate to their temperatures.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that Y dwarfs follow surprisingly predictable patterns when organized by temperature and color, forming tight sequences on astronomical charts with far less scatter than previously observed. However, when they compared their measurements to theoretical models‚Äîcomputer simulations that predict how these objects should appear‚Äîthey found systematic mismatches. The models consistently predicted colors that were too red compared to reality, suggesting our understanding of atmospheric physics at these extreme cold temperatures remains incomplete.

**Looking Forward**

These precise measurements provide a crucial reality check for atmospheric models used to interpret exoplanet observations. As next-generation telescopes prepare to study Earth-like worlds around other stars, having accurate models becomes essential for determining which planets might harbor conditions suitable for life.
